{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3604856,"name":"Tom Praisner","username":"TJP1699","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tjp1699/{size}/216696_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-27T01:05:11.802Z","cooked":"

External elevator rigging (outside of extrusions) requires mounting of pulleys and often, the addition of guides to keep lines on the pulleys.

External rigging can also be challenging when designing an articulating elevator that serves multiple functions like a “back[ack” deep climb in Reefscape (2025)

On Martin Luther King day this year, our Design-Team had a great discussion that resulted in us identifying some fortuitous features of our recently purchased SDS elevator blocks. We had asked ourselves the question, “How can we simplify the rigging or our elevator?” Through our deliberations, we noted that the shafts that support the ball bearings (not the cam followers) of our SDS elevator blocks could accommodate the mounting of a simple pulley that makes internal, UHMWPE-based rigging quite simple.

A key benefit of this approach is that it does not require any machining of the tube stock /extrusion used to build the elevator. It also nearly eliminates the need to mount any pulleys externally on the elevator. You can see in the images below that we only had to design dual-pulley turns at the bottom of our elevator to turn the lines towards our spool.

For the pulleys mounted on the SDS elevator blocks, we designed simple, 3D-printed pulleys and press fit COTS roller bearings into them. The roller bearings we used are the drawn-cup type with 1/4" ID, 7/16" OD, and 7/16" wide. They can be purchased from McMaster Carr or Amazon.

We purchased 1/4" stainless shaft stock which we cut to length to replace the shafts of the SDS elevator blocks. We also printed simple spacers to keep our pulleys centered on our new stainless shafts.

To allow our UHMWPE lines to pass through the SDS elevator blocks into our elevator tubes, we bored out the center mounting-bolt holes of the SDS elevator blocks in our drill press (see images below).

For tensioning, we employed easily made tensioning elements in the top tubes on each side of our elevator. These “turnbuckles” consisted of a tube block with the center holed drilled out to 1/4" with a 3", fully-threaded 10-32 socket-head bolt passing downward through the tube block. A tapped 3/8" hex shaft, ~3.5 inches long was threaded and placed on the end of the socket-head bolt. We put 200lb rated stainless split-ring fishing line connectors on the ends of each tensioner, to which we attached our UHMWPE lines. These rings are designed to yield at approximately 200lbs load to ensure that if there is a programming or operational error, the rings yield before the lines or some mechanical element fails. This happened to our climber in 2024 and we endeavor to design in frangibility like this now. Finally, this tensioning turnbuckle (shown in the pictures below), was inserted into our top stage extrusions and the tube blocks were bolted within the very top of the extrusions. We added a 3D-printed collar with a square outer profile on the turnbuckle hex shaft. This was done to keep the hex shaft from spinning within the top-stage extrusion. In this way we could simply tighten the 3" socket-head bolt to tension the elevator lines.

A key benefit of the SDS elevator blocks with these mods is that the resulting lines run within and between our elevator tubes are nearly perfectly parallel to the elevator tubes. This makes tensioning a breeze in that the line tension stays constant across the full range of elevator extension.

Below are some images of our simplified rigging. We hope this helps other teams that are not quite up to machining extrusion for internal belt rigging.

Overview images of our robot:

3U3A65081920×2880 639 KB

A55I39901920×2880 465 KB

Elevator underbelly showing spool and the only exposed UHMWPE lines:

DSC049641920×2880 499 KB

Image of UHMWPE lines running between our elevator extrusion elements:

DSC049541920×1280 192 KB

Image showing the top of our fixed stage and the SDS elevator block with our pulley and spacer mods in between the two ball bearings. The UHMWPE line can be seen here running over the black PLA pulley:

DSC049581920×1280 136 KB

Image of one of our bearing-block pulleys with roller bearing and an attendant spacer. It would be ideal to make the pulley out of aluminum, but it was beyond our means this year.

DSC050011920×1280 174 KB

Here one can see the top of both stages on one side of our elevator. Also note, the black plastic tube-end plug in the very top of our last moving stage can be removed to access the socket-head bolt of our internal tensioning turnbuckle:

DSC049691920×2880 300 KB

Elevator tensioning turnbuckles before being inserted into the top of our top-stage extrusions:

DSC048951920×1280 186 KB

Finally, here are two images of our only external pulleys. They are mounted on the bottom of our elevator to take the lines out of the fixed stage and reorient them to travel to our spool:

DSC049921920×2880 432 KB

DSC049891920×2880 392 KB

Again, hope this helps teams that, like us, may not be able to achieve internal, continuously belt-rigged elevators just yet.

What was the process for running the elevator rigging? Drop the line down the tube with a small weight attached? Can it be done after the elevator is assembled? I’m not seeing how you can easily get the line out of the tube with both tube plugs on.

Ah, good question. Due to an assembly mistake, we rigged the elevator twice during the build process. We essentially sewed the lines through each of our elevator tube segments with the carbon-fiber rods listed below. We taped the end of the UHMWPE line to the end of the tube to use the rod like a needle. Once we got the hang of it, it took 5-10 minutes to do each side of the elevator. No disassembly of the elevator was required.
2mm x 1000mm Carbon Fiber RODS

Looks great!
I had the same idea right before kickoff XD

image1920×1342 69.8 KB

I ended up not taking it further because of the really small bend radius, but it looks like it worked for you! Did you have any of the idlers fail?

My “solution” was custom bearing blocks for internal belt for teams with no tube router. LYNK ran this elevator all of 2025:

Belted Continous In-tube no tube manufacturing elevator Technical Discussion
[Thin_2_Stage_Example_8] Well, that was a long title. Two months ago I had an idea (and a challenge) to make a COTS-compatible belt in-tube elevator. [{71BCC078-BD41-4D3C-9826-332B1D31D097}] The main constraint was that teams had to be able to manufacture a continuous elevator with no tube CNC and just a band saw and a vendor kit. My first iteration revolved around giant billet bearing blocks, which wasn’t workable. (Thank you to @thevedantin for trying to make it workable) [Bearing Blo…

Yes, we had to replace some of the 3D-printed pulleys once. On our second version of the pulleys, we reduced the depth of the groove to thicken the PLA on which the UHMWPE directly runs on. It would be better to print them from something tougher than PLA, or machine them from aluminum.

If you mean the simple CAD for the pulley and the spacers, sure, here it is. You definitely want to print the pulleys at 100% infill.

cad.onshape.com

IMG_92021072×1648 511 KB

Excuse my drawing but this is the idea. The green marks the two spots on the spool where the extension strings attach. The red marks where the retraction string attaches, and the yellow marks where it attaches to the carriage. The blue attempts to show the flow of the string.

The string goes down from the spool and is redirected by two pulleys to the inside of the outside stage. It goes up through the stage, runs along the pulley on the bearing block, and then down between the outside stage and the first moving stage. This repeats for the first moving stage into the innermost stage. Inside the innermost stage the string is connected to the loops that we use for tensioning which are photographed above and here.

The string runs through the “bottom” stage from this frame of reference, and then moves between the bottom stage and the middle stage.

The string is tied to the loops on these components, which are mounted to each end of the final stage of the elevator.

Hope this helps, not sure it will, might just be more confusing. @TJP1699 please correct me if I got any of this wrong.
